Brazil is in the midst of a presidential election.

NPR's Lourdes Garcia-Navarro has our story from Sao Paulo.
The race is on.
Dilma Rousseff will face right-of-center candidate Aecio Neves in the runoff for the presidency.

(Speaking Portuguese).

The candidates will have an equal amount of time on TV.
Neves is good on TV, so I think who will win is unpredictable, he says.

Neves rose in the polls.
(Speaking Portuguese).
Pereira says Neves appeals to people who want change, but he also has a history that represents security and continuity.

His party is right-of-center and held the presidency right before Rousseff's mentor, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, came to power in 2002.

Well, let's scroll forward about 75 years in time and talk to Brad Matsen about these two gentlemen, Otis Barton and William Beebe, who kind of were an odd couple, but they came together to design and build and then operate this thing called the bathysphere.
What was that and what was it intended to do?
Well, Joe, the bathysphere was basically a sphere cast out of steel, paid for by Otis Barton.
And in it, he and William Beebe made dives to--their greatest depths was about 3,000 feet.
And nothing like this had ever been done before.
In fact, no humans had ever descended beyond sunlight until they did it.
And why--I mean, what was their--were they adventure seekers?
Were they scientists?
What were their goals?

As Dr. Rozwadowski mentioned, the confluence of technology was enormous, and these men happened to intersect with Bessemer steel which was hard enough to withstand the pressure of the deep; with quartz glass and with certain kinds of cables that would allow them to stay safe on their dive and to get some electricity down so they could look out the window.
There isn't much point in going down there unless you look outside.
William Beebe was arguably the most famous naturalist and science popularizer of his time, and he was well-known; he had published 15 books by the time he went down in the bathysphere.
Otis Barton was an adventurer, a young man with a very large trust fund, and he paid the bills.
And they met in 1928.
And two years later, they made their first dive off Bermuda into the Atlantic Ocean to a depth of 800 feet.
And it was frightening.
This is not a book for the claustrophobic and it's not story for the claustrophobic.
Crawling into a four-and-a-half-foot steel ball, two people--it really looks about like there's room for a large dog inside.
And they went inside with tanks of oxygen so they could breathe and open trays of chemicals to absorb the moisture and the carbon dioxide, which, of course, everybody knows about since Apollo 13.
But this craft that these men were diving in was the equivalent of a spacecraft.
And when I first came across it, it was under the roller coaster in Coney Island...

That's such an amazing story.
